awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer and UV Excimer Laser Platform for Trace Element Analysis and U-Th-Pb Petrochronology
awd_abstract_narration:
An Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer and UV Excimer Laser for Geology at Boise State University

The Department of Geosciences at Boise State University will acquire a state-of-the-art ultraviolet laser probe and an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer. This acquisition will enable new and innovative methodologies of trace element and isotopic analysis of Earth materials. The requested instrumentation is an integral component of the Boise State University Isotope Geology Laboratory for research projects in Earth Sciences. The new lab will work with partners including the Boise State University Office of STEM and Diversity Initiatives, and hundreds of collaborators to broaden the participation of women and minorities and persons with disabilities in science.

The Department of Geosciences at Boise State University will acquire a state-of-the-art ultraviolet (UV) excimer laser probe with a high-sensitivity, fast-washout, two-volume ablation cell, fully integrated with a turn-key, fast-scanning, high-sensitivity, large dynamic range, quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICPMS). This acquisition will leverage an existing laboratory infrastructure, human resources, and a decade of LA-ICPMS experience by the PIs into new and innovative methodologies of trace element and isotopic analysis of Earth materials, including applications to magmatic systems, metamorphism and tectonics, and paleoclimatic, paleobiological, and sediment provenance proxy records of Earth systems dynamics. The requested instrumentation is an integral component of innovative tandem in situ and isotope dilution analytical workflows that the Boise State University Isotope Geology Laboratory applies to the full spectrum of geochronological and petrochronological problems in Earth sciences. The new facility will:  Foster the next generation of geochronology-expert Earth systems scientists by mentoring visiting scientists and students who will receive knowledge and training in analytical techniques that are exported to other labs and institutions over time;  Promote cross-disciplinary training for non-specialists on the role of laser ablation geochronology through the week-long IsoAstro summer workshop;  Engage a network of partners including on-campus NSF S-STEM scholarship programs, the Boise State University Office of STEM and Diversity Initiatives, and a broad base of hundreds of previous and current collaborators including the NSF AGeS2 graduate research award program, to broaden the participation of women and traditionally underrepresented minorities and persons with disabilities in the LA-ICPMS laboratory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) provided funds to acquire a quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer and 193 nm excimer laser probe peripheral for the Isotope Geology Laboratory (IGL) of the Department of Geosciences, Boise State University. The IGL combines analytical tools and expert personnel to develop and apply in situ and high-precision U-Th-Pb geochronology, radiogenic isotope tracers, and both in situ and bulk sample major and trace element analysis to a broad spectrum of problems in Earth and environmental science.

The new instrumentation has doubled the plasma analytical capacity of the IGL, and is helping to meet the burgeoning needs of the national user community for state-of-the-art applications including: screening of complex marine and terrestrial volcanigenic samples for high-precision, high-accuracy U-Pb dating for chronostratigraphy, paleobiology and paleoclimatology; basaltic to silicic glass composition analysis for applications ranging from ocean basin magmatic evolution to terrestrial basin tephrochronology; tandem in situ (LA-ICPMS) and isotope dilution (TIMS) analysis of detrital zircons for robust maximum age constraints; coupling of in situ geochemical and isotopic analyses to high-precision analyses of the same grains to explore silicic volcanic and plutonic igneous processes; the characterization and calibration of mineral standard materials for in situ geochronology and geochemistry; and near-surface isotopic and elemental depth profiling of mineral grains to understand the exhumation and erosion of mountain belts.

In addition to the provision of geochronological services to a broad segment of the Earth Sciences community, the IGL promotes student and early-career scientist training and multi-disciplinary integration through in-person analytical visits to use the LA-ICPMS instrumentation. The added instrumentation also provides enhanced opportunities for more intensive training in elemental and isotope ratio mass spectrometry for postdoctoral fellows and graduate students focused on careers in analytical science and technology. The LA-ICPMS instrumentation is also embedded in data-collection activities in several undergraduate courses at Boise State, promoting a variety of experiential learning opportunities in our curriculum.

Beyond the principle Earth Science disciplines studied by IGL investigators and collaborators, the capabilities of both solution and laser ablation analysis by ICPMS have also been used by materials scientists at Boise State University in materials characterization for battery technology and nuclear fuel cycle materials. The LA-ICPMS instrumentation has also been vital to fostering new relationships between the IGL and various state geological surveys that have an unmet need for U-Pb zircon geochronology associated with geologic mapping and resource delineation.  These geologic maps are used by a variety of public and private sector stakeholders for diverse uses from mineral resource extraction, to transportation network planning, to energy and water resources management.
